messageBody:
Agreed. Documentation and comments should provide the WHY and the code
should clearly spell out the HOW and WHAT. For instance, look at any of the
javadoc comments in the java.util package. They give book references, time
statistics, pre-conditions, and post-conditions. This type of documentation
is incredibly useful. But I've seen many stupid javadoc comments like this:

/** Returns the ID of the object */
public int getId() {
return this.id;
}

Last night I commented a for loop because it was preferable to a while loop
due to the remote possibility of a infinite loop. This was so I don't come
back later and say "Why was I doing this the hard way?".

-----Original Message-----
From: Andy Kriger [mailto:kokaku@...]
Sent: Monday, February 18, 2002 1:34 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: OT: RE: [junit] Re: JavaDocs


While generally true, it is often useful to document why a certain
implementation decision was made over another. How often do you look at old
code or someone else's code and wonder now why did I/they do it that way?
This becomes very handy during refactoring efforts where it is easy to
forget that a chunk code is there for a specific reason that should be
accounted for.

-----Original Message-----
From: Eric Heikkila [mailto:ericheikkila@...]
Sent: Monday, 18 February, 2002 16:21
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: OT: RE: [junit] Re: JavaDocs



--- "Stevens, Timothy J. (LNG-MBC)"
<timothy.j.stevens@...> wrote:
>
> If you remove the Javadocs from the code, they'll
> never get updated
> and will quickly become the useless docs that you
> hate. If you take an extra
> 30 seconds to keep your Javadocs up to date when you
> make any changes to a
> class's methods, you'll find they're not a pain at
> all. If you wait until
> you're finished coding then try to put them all in,
> though, I can see why
> you'd hate them.
>
> And what's wrong with having them in the code? Do
> you not believe in
> comments, either? Javadocs provide a nice structure
> for commenting methods
> and classes, better than the random comment formats
> you typically see in
> C/C++ coding.
>
> -tim

Correct...can't stand comments. The code should be
fairly straightforward and self-documenting. If I
HAVE to read a bunch of comments to figure the code
out, the code needs to be ripped out and redone.

-Eric
